CatDescriptText: Miss Janet Fleishman, secretary, North Side and Mr. W.L. Reynolds, Alcoa employee, New Kensington, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 10, 1962, pg. 7 with question: "Who had the more dangerous assignment--Lindbergh or Glenn?" Miss Janet Fleishman's answer reads: "I think Glenn, because Lindberg knew what was going on, whereas Glenn was not so sure about the space and was traveling in the unknown.  Glenn is a very brave man."  Mr. W.L. Reynolds' answer reads: "Both were tough assignments...Lindberg, perhaps, was the braver because he was facing a completely unknown atmosphere, wheras [sic] Glenn had been preceded by others-- two Americans and one Russian."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Janet Fleishman wearing flecked coat, standing in front of store window; Portrait of W.L. Reynolds wearing coat and hat, standing in front of store window with sign for "Health Foods" and two pedestrians
